(Same as EAS 370 1)


This class explores the evolution of Japanese history from ancient times to the dawn of the modern era. It uses art and literature to investigate various aspects of society, the economy, culture, religion, and politics. Key topics include Japan's relations with the outside world; the rise of the imperial institution; and the evolution of aristocratic, samurai, and townspeople's culture. In broader terms, our approach will draw attention to such theoretical issues as the tensions between center & peripheries; identity (self and Other; insiders and outsiders); and history from above versus history from below. Previous knowledge of Japanese history or Japanese language welcome, but not required.
